dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garish purple light spills out of side-street porno house illuminating a silhouette, and little else, of a MAN lean against an alley wall. He is waiting. Another silhouetted FIGURE appears and approaches the fir They size each other up as best they can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacLeod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second nods. The first without hesitation raises a sword, the intended thrust interrupted by his own death as the second with a of metal severs the agressor's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 15th century Scottish home. A haggard WOMAN, her small CHILD clinging to a tattered a stands hunched over a glowing hearth.  Her veined hands d a wooden spoon around and around through a soot-covered p of grey soup. From an adjoining room CONOR MACLEOD, a young man dressed in his best traditional Celtic tartan, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, but are you the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surveying himself) It's a bit tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His FATHER enters with a pail of milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Conor, how you look a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you time for some- thing to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mother.  They'll be here shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor's father looks him over with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your grandfather wore that in his service to the King, and I to fight for the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  It is his duty.  All of ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ian, he's still but a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a MacLeod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several HORSEMEN gallop up through the early morning fog the cottage door. Conor's father steps out to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive KNIGHT sits astride his horse, moorish dew clin ing to his helmet and breastplate.  A CLANSMAN hikes up t heather-carpeted slope to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the boy among them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second kneels to examine the headless body of the fir With a CLACK a window, high on the alley wall, closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DUKE is leading a brigade of CLANSMEN out onto the pl Mounted VASSALS ride back and forth inspecting the line. low fog makes it impossible to see beyond a few yards.  T is an erie, smothering silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is a bad day for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke has been compro- mised.  He will have his due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By day's end he will have our heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ride against the Suther- lands.  That is all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes no sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: And a friend are marching through the moist heather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fog is bad.  We cannot even see the sides of our own ranks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor's nervousness is showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOUTING is heard on the plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight, above the fog, hears the battle commence belo He spurs his horse and starts down into the mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two opposing clans are now one confused mass of tarta and clashing swords.  The air is charged with SHOUTS of e citement, agony, and the SHRILL of bag pipes. The fog has made each man's battle his own, each isolated his opponent.

dialogues.speaker: THE KNIGHT
dialogues.text: Rides calmly through the fracas.  He strikes and kills th that assault him, but appears disinterested in battle. He is looking.

dialogues.speaker: CONOR
dialogues.text: Is standing above the twitching body of his friend. Alone and confused, Conor has become seperated from the c He stumbles through the fog, seeking help. Suddenly he is alone with the Knight. The face of iron locks its gaze onto the boy.  His fear t to panic, Conor turns and flees. The Knight, his resolve steeled in a raised sword, kicks horse into persuit. Conor is easily overtaken and on his first pass the Knigh brings his blade down hard into Conor's shoulder, slicing open most of the boy's back and knocking him face-first i the heather. As Conor watches his own blood spew forth, he rolls over time to see the Knight dismount and start for him.

dialogues.speaker: THE KNIGHT
dialogues.text: Leans down next to Conor, his metal face nearly against t boy's.  His voice slithers out of the iron in almost a wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There can be but one.

dialogues.speaker: A CLANSMAN
dialogues.text: Charges out of the fog and attacks the Knight, who cuts h nearly in half.  ANOTHER wanders in and meets the same fa The battle is shifting to where they are. Not finished yet with Conor, the Knight is finding himsel forced into retreat from an ever increasing number of ass ants.

dialogues.speaker: A VASSAL
dialogues.text: Sees his men being hacked apart trying to stop the now-mo Knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clansmen obey. With the slap of an armored gauntlet against his steed, t Knight disappears into the fog. The Vassal surveys the carnage before him.  His eyes fall moment on the moaning, gurgling Conor. The Vassal turns and leaves the boy for dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patrol car pauses at the mouth of the alley. The figure considers his situation, then quickly shoves h sword into a near-by drain.  He straightens up and waits.

dialogues.speaker: AN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Steps out of his unit and cautiously walks forward.  His switches on the patrol car's side lamps, bathing the alle in a harsh glare.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN ALLEY
dialogues.text: For the first time we can see his face.  RICHARD TAUPIN, in a well-cut business suit, looks exactly like Conor. The police officer, upon seeing the body, grabs instincti for his pistol.  He yells to his partner now coming into alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin!  Get is a backup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was merely walking by when-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer has his pistol out and leveled. His partner runs up, shotgun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice cuts short as the blood flows against his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor lies moaning on a cot.  Makeshift bandages wrap his body, stained and pasted by thick, dried blood. The family surrounds their dying son. A PRIEST is delivering the last rites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Libera Domine Animan servi tui sicut libertasi David de manu regis Saul...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sobbing mother holds a compress to Conor's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In mamus tuas domine commendo spiritum meum...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Vassal rides up to the hutch, dismounts, and approaches CLANSMAN standing in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the boy died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is having the last rites now.  It should be over by morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never seen anybody cut as bad live so long.  He should have died on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight or tomorrow, it's all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vassal peers inside at the priest administering the sacraments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Auditorium nostrum in nomine domini...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been a dark day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Requiescant in pace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a bustle of activity.  Setting up barricades, un formed OFFICERS are trying to keep NEW CREWS and curious ONLOOKERS at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE LT. MORAN
dialogues.text: Lean, fortyish, and comfortable with the gore in front of is inspecting the corpse with a MEDICAL EXAMINER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying body) Real clean.  No sawing action at all.  Whatever it was did it in one swipe. (looks up at Moran) Like the other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran gestures to a sword, wrapped in plastic, lying near

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't any blood on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) About the only thing that doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give it a closer look when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNA CARTWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Pretty but not beautiful, thirtyish, she exudes a sort of insolent intelligence. An OFFICER sees her duck under a police barricade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Brenna, you know better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks to where the medical examiner is organizing his equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greeting) Mr. Levine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The examiner turns and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope this isn't past your bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna looks to the now-sheeted corpse, blood flowing fro where the head should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't have a head, does he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one came unassembled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Moran is standing near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no warmth) Just show her what she came for, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands, taps Brenna's arm) Come on, this is more your line of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna and the examiner walk the few yards from the corps to the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your uncle?  I hardly ever see him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The examiner stops and gestures to the weapon clothed in forensic plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna's expression changes to interest as she kneels dow beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't look like it came from "Toys-Are-Us", that's why I called you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up in Moran's direction) Didn't think it was my buddy over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured you knew more about swords than I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scottish claymore.  Take a French epee, add twenty pounds of ballast so it means business, and you've got a claymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (runs hand along hilt, slightly confused) It's in good condition.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD TAUPIN
dialogues.text: Is being put in the rear of a patrol car.  Brenna studies face in the half-gloom.  There's something different abou A steadiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Taupin is seated at a graffitti scrawled table in room otherwise bare of furnishings.  He seems unphased by surroundings. The door opens and Moran enters with bag and notebook.  H picks up Taupin's wallet on the table top and checks the driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your present address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr.- (looks at license) Taupin, what were you doing in that alley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was walking by when I heard a shout.  Your men came right after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know the victim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name was Iman Fasil if that jogs your memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was carrying a Syrian passport and had been in the country less than a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin's face is stoic and controlled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days ago a Bulgarian national was murdered the same way.  He'd also been in the country less than a week. (beat) What is your citizenship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran paces to a corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you make a habit of hanging out in that neigh- borhood at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say that in my years with this department I've seen more than one well dressed business man look for a hand job on 14th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran places both hands on the table and leans across it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were _you_ looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran reaches into a bag on the table and removes a large broad sword; old, but in mint condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I presume it's a sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A claymore to be exact.  You wouldn't know anything about it would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your murder weapon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was covered with Mr. Fasil's fingerprints, but none of his blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran turns the sword over in his hand then sets it down. He rises and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Mr. Taupin, we'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin passes through the doorway without comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin out into the crisp night air.  His eyes search out darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medieval sun beats down on an OLD TRAVELER making his w the MacLeod home.  Conor's mother, scrubbing clothes in a bucket, smiles in recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah Steven, it is good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a kind man to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven, Conor didn't die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I had heard his wounds were mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perched on a heather-carpeted rise above the village a yo woman, MARA, sits contemplating the intricaces of a daffo Balancing on a shepard's staff, Conor limps over and puts his lips to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mara is silent.  Distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your future husband, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no future husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  Not a week ago your father gave us his blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is difficult for her.  Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I did live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why the crazy talk?  It's a miracle it is.  Saint Andrew has smiled on me.  On us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some think not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mad.  Surely you don't take their word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sounding like that mad woman, Widow Baggins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me father has taken back my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a hand to her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Lassie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please not be touching me, Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not take that kind of talk from you.  From those others below, maybe.  But not from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, Conor.  Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not talking sense, Mara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anger tumbles into exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps for her.  She moves away.  Conor's face hardens resentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you send me away now, Mara, I'll not come looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Do what you must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resigned, Conor turns and limps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classy antiques.  Unusual.  Clocks, tables, chests.  Smal personal. Richard Taupin enters and sheds his overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Thompson agreed to settle for fifteen, Melvin's wants to make a pick-up at three o'clock, the coffee machine's broken, and there's a Miss Cartwright from the Smithsonian in your office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin is hardly in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna Cartwright stands in Taupin's cluttered surroundin admiring a bagpipe set neatly on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very traditional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin sits down and begins sorting through a stack of pa on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Miss Cartwright, what is it I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to ask you about the claymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite rare you know, some- thing so common in its time so well looked after all these years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Cartwright, unless you have come here to sell the sword, there's very little I can help you with.  Now if you will excuse me, I have a great deal of work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna has taken a carving from the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Byzantine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basil the II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming guy, Basil.  Once after beating an army of Serbians he blinded all but-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -All but one out of a hundred, I know.  All left to be led like donkeys back home.  Now if you will please-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna suddenly tosses the carving at him.  Taupin snatch out of the air with lightning precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good reflexes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Miss Cartwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely, ancient room full of equal parts dust and oaken study tables. The department SUPERVISOR sits at his desk surrounded by handful of his staff RESEARCHERS - Brenna included.  A fa stern portrait of some forgotten curator presides over pr up feet, cold coffee, and half eaten sack lunches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's too cool.  Too sharp.  I think he's got something to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, has your penetrating research on 9th Century Lithuanian dildos suddenly made you an expert on the criminal mentality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw off, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men, LAUGH.  They delight in baiting her. Researcher #2 opens a Budweiser and pours the beer into a mug he's borrowed from the collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops bought it.  They let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could they hold him for?  I think they're just waiting for something concrete before they haul him in for real.  We should look into it.  He had to have gotten that sword from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on a sec, you did your little favor for the boys downtown, I'm sure your uncle and the rest are perfectly capable of taking it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen nobleman swords that weren't as well preserved.  It's just a hunk of peasant iron.  Why would he be carrying it around in an alley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.  Everytime there's a murder in town we have to put up with junior D.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be genetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone should check him out. Maybe a collection somewhere got knocked over.  He has one, he might have two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that desk?  _Your_ desk?  You see the crap piled up on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a rest Ned, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be interesting to see what his family connections are.  That's a hell of a piece to be just chuck- ing around in an alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) I swear to God Brenna, between you and Thompson's novels I'm going to get a bloody ulcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Researcher #2 lifts the mug of beer to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty mug is set on the counter of a medieval drinking establishment. CLANSMEN, their faces and clothes smudged with a day's wo the fields, relax and enjoy the company of their fellow V No longer requiring the use of a cane, Conor enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to owner) Evening, Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tavern goes silent.  Wary.  The attention is on Conor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale suits me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner unenthusiastically fills Conor a mug.  Conor ta it and walks to where four other VILLAGERS sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We rather you not be sitting with us, Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks to the next table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We be drinking alone as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire tavern spells the same sentiments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Angered, Conor approaches the second man.  As he looms ab his chair the man in genuine fear pulls out a cross and t it forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Requiem acer'nam donaei-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Et lux perpetua-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll not be bringing the church into this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Luceat ei-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weird display frightens Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Auditorium nostrum-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -In nomine sanctus esperitu-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor HURLES his mug against the wall. His nerves shattered, he rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor packs a satchel with his few clothes and belongings He walks to the doorway where his mother and father wait. His mother, tears on her cheek, hugs him tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor turns to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish there was some other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clasp hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without looking back he passes through the doorway and do empty path, his figure quickly fading in the moorish fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NOISY business-as-usual confusion at the Washington P processing center. Amongst the dinge of CLANGING phones and CLACKING typewri a uniformed OFFICER enters something into a computer term Brenna sits perched on a desk nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is against the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So's playing choo-choo with two high school cheerleaders in the middle of-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Okay okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me.  Besides, I'm cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The computer returns a reply onto a printer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears off sheet) Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born March 16, 1945 in Church Hill, Maryland.  Received first driver permit 1967 in Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church Hill, that's pretty close, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything in Maryland is close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin steps out of a Metro station and walks the few blo to his brick townhouse.  Climbing the front stairs, he fi his keys out of a coat pocket.  About to insert the key h sensing something. Backing down the steps, Taupin slips around to the rear o building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a spider Taupin pries open a window and slips silent inside. The home is dark and still. Taupin creeps down the hallway and peers into the entrywa There a MAN, dressed in a tuxedo jacket and nearly imperc in the dim light, is crouched at the front door. He is holding a sword. Taupin removes a knife from his pocket and JUMPS the intr The two STRUGGLE fiercely. Taupin pins the intruder against the carpet and shoves hi knife firmly against the man's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bulging eyes stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What name is he using?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin presses the blade.  A trickle of blood rolls down throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith.  Carl Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Bulgarian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got him. (hoarse chuckle) He always does.  Eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows I'm here.  How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of this would be happening if you hadn't run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knife is pressed deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: _Answer_ me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A city limit sign announcing the small community of Churc Hill is overtaken by Brenna's sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna looks through a telephone book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin...Taupin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  She closes the book and drums her fingers on th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 1860s stone columned affair, far more impressive than low-lying town that surrounds it. Brenna enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna sits sifting through a large cloth-bound book enti _Certificates of Birth: 1941-1948_.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Tarmin...Tatum...Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born to William and Karen Taupin, no address.  Attend- ing physician, Dr. Willis Kidell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kidell stands at his bookcase leafing through a binde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1945, that strains the memory. (after a fashion) Here we are, Richard Taupin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries the binder to the table where Brenna sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like more tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kidell sips his own and looks over the binder page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was unsual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is a small town, and it was even smaller then.  Most all the babies I delivered were from local families.  Richard's parents were just passing through when his mother's time came.  I did it right here at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you didn't know Richard later on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to find somebody who knew him and any connections his family might have had with museums or historical societies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know about any of that. Suppose nobody does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor little tyke didn't have a chance.  Hopelessly premature.  He died a few days after he was born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy _died_?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother too.  Sad case it was.  The young lady just couldn't make it through labor.  Never even saw her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kidell removes from the binder a tattered newspaper c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother worked for the town paper at the time.  He took this picture of the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something in the clipping sparks Brenna's interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to anyone else about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was this one fella.  Asked a lot of questions.  I was out of town but I heard he spent near a full day in the records office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you remember his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) Carl Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police line-up. Seven MEN, all dressed in Santa Claus outfits with bare l are paraded for a small, old LADY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell us when you see the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several rows back in the dark sits Brenna's UNCLE JOE, th district attorney, and another man, his ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're never "just curious". (to assistant) You've met my neice, Brenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Brenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to line-up) Number 5, lift your coat up more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you getting a little old for this?  You flunked out of law school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) Now there's a new topic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they have enough for you to do at the castle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna puts on her best little-girl angelic smile, a smil uncle can never refuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Forgers do it all the time.  They take the birth certificate of some- one who died young and use it to get legit I.D.  Usually they carry it long enough to pass some bad checks then dump it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call your mother.  You never call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to old lady) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'd have to see his thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swath of moonlight shines in across a carafe-turned-vas a New England college diploma, and a police uniform hangi from the bedpost where Brenna lies with another man, DENN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't figure out why he's doing it. He's been Richard Taupin at least since 1967.  And the guys rich.  You should see the stuff he has in that shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's hiding from something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some guy named Smith was asking about him in Church Hill.  I passed his name around with your buddies downtown but they drew a blank.  So he isn't a cop.  District anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis gets out of bed and begins putting on his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably just some exec ducking an ex-wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kidell had a picture in his file of the funeral.  The father looked just like Richard.  Even had a mark on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is Richard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.D. says 41, but he barely looks 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find the father.  That should clear things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He buttons his shirt.  Something occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin, isn't that the guy Moran picked up the other night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd want to know about all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Congeniality?  Let him find his own clues.  There's a journal article in this somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Uncle Joey's little girl.  Can't get the taste out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis puts on his police cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the cream of society awaits. (cocks hat to one side) If you're ever in the neighborhood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE OFFICERS, their flashlights cutting the darkness, the mud shores of a Potomac tidal basin.  The glowing Jef Memorial can be seen in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE MORAN
dialogues.text: Is supervising.  An OFFICER climbs up the embankment to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer leads him down to the river where a headless wearing a tuxedo jacket is being put into a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was about fifty yards down- stream from the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran looks down at the body bag, its dark plastic reflec the rythmic rotation of squad car beacons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both were cut real clean.  Like the other ones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steeple-chase course lies shrouded in an Arlington fog. Across the damp grass a lone horse, heaving clouds of war breath, leaps gracefully over a hurdle.  Driving the stee hard through the course, Taupin pulls firm on the reins, bringing horse and rider to a shuddering stop where Detec Moran waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been another murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin lifts his eyes to the suburban treeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you Tuesday night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighbor saw your car leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin climbs down from his horse.  Moran moves close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know what the hell you're up to, but I think I've got a pretty good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I need is time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got all the time in the world. (looks at watch) Except right now.  If you will excuse me, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In no hurry, Taupin leads his horse away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna sits surrounded by books of old English law, color family banner plates, and a medieval caltrap sitting on h desk corner. Boring quickly, she shuts the book and sighs.  From anoth folder she pulls out a computer sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police sheet has Taupin's name and motor vehicle reco Below are listed four WILLIAM TAUPINS, their hometowns an driving records.  Richard Taupin's first driver permit wa 1967. Brenna looks down the list to a WILLIAM TAUPIN of Felton, Delaware, who stopped filling for driver permits in 1967, year Richard started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropping a couple of quarters into a vending machine, Bre removes and opens up a map of the State of Delaware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna steps out of her car at a small town cemetary. Holding a slip of paper, she weaves her way through the s covered tombs of revolutionary heroes and their descendan On a small rise fresh dirt lies in careless piles around open grave. Richard Taupin stands at the mouth of the pit. A coffin has been brutally pulled from the dirt and lies and propped diagonally beside a marker that reads: "WILLI MICHAEL TAUPIN". The casket is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone beat you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grave robbers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People like that rarely leave business cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Carl Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of interest, quickly suppressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do.  Better yet, I don't think anything was stolen because nothing was there in the first place. And I think Mr. Smith, whoever he is, now knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an active imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been to Church Hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Cartwright, you are involving yourself in matters that do not concern you.  I strongly suggest you return to Washington and stay out of small town cemetaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt that. (beat) Good day, Miss Cartwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks on. After only a few paces Taupin suddenly shudders to an abr stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up an open palm to silence her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your help may be unneccessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is still. Taupin's face is expressionless.  He listens intently.  S An unseen voice rides seemingly on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Good afternoon, "Mr. Taupin".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin whirls around to see a large man standing with bro sword in hand.  We have never seen the knight out of his before, but this man certainly seems to fit the bill.  We Levis and leather jacket in contrast to Taupin's expensiv business suit, he speaks with icy evenness from a face of Taupin, naked without his own sword, is trapped against a marble wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight is closing in on him, sword gripped in both ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been here from the start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My quarry grows clever with age.  And the others, incompetent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight throws Brenna a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of sorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do hope she enjoys a good show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight leans his whole body into a two-fisted swing, clanging out a chunk of marble as Taupin ducks. A second swipe also imbeds itself in stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now it ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thrust cuts only air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Generation upon generation. Tens of thousands of miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin leaps behind a tree.  The Knight cuts it nearly in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the last, MacLeod. Romirez, Lacroux, Neuvich, those fools that followed me, their heads all line my shelf.  All but yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin drops to the ground in a shoulder roll to avoid a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you feel it, MacLeod? Can you _feel_ it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin grabs a tree branch and raps the Knight on the kne knocking him over. The Knight quickly rights himself and cuts the branch fro Taupin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There can be but one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his blade. An elderly WATCHMAN, shotgun cradled in his arms, stands the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight pauses a split second then with decision launc his sword spear-style firmly into the watchman's chest. Taupin pushes past him to Brenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna is frozen in shock. Taupin shoves her roughly toward the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MACLEOD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight retrieves his sword from the watchman's body a lumbers after them. Taupin and Brenna bolt from the cemetary and into the sur ing residential area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin leads an exhausted Brenna in a gallop down the sid walk. They have apparently lost the Knight.  Taupin pauses at a corner.  He sees a church across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna enters and collapses into a pew, her labored breat echoing off the high ceiling. Taupin walks the length of an aisle to see that they are Satisfied, he leans against a banister and considers his uation. Trying to recover her wind, Brenna has her eyes closed an head against the back of the pew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be safe here.  He won't kill in a church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Tradition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin stares out the window, stained glass shining orang his face.  He looks at Brenna briefly, then passes throug Church's doorway without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glowing horseshoe HISSES wildly as it slips into a wood cooling bucket.  Pulling it out with iron tongs, Conor la it on a counter and pounds it even with a mallet. Sweaty and streaked with dirt, he tosses the mallet aside and walks out into the late afternoon sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor leans over a water barrel and dunks his head and ar cleaning off a day's worth of sweat and grime.

dialogues.speaker: JUAN ROMIREZ
dialogues.text: Stirring up dust with his travelling boots, this Spanish ented man stops at Conor's shop.  He wears a large broad strapped to his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Conor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bows slightly) Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (notices accent) You're not from these parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am from Spain.  And I would like a moment of your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez is seated at a table.  His back to the Spaniard, Conor is preparing some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't much to offer, Mr. Romirez from Spain, but you're welcome to what's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please go to no trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez is looking at the faint, pale hint of a scar that runs from Conor's shoulder blade to his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your back, it would seem perhaps you were injured in battle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years past me clan fought another over some- thing I cannot even re- member.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your marks would suggest great injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was nearly killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks up from his work in pained memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And but for a mark you are well as any man, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should imagine that your recovery must have alarmed your fellow villagers, perhaps giving them reason to invent an explanation.  And a solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something isn't right. Conor turns and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was driven out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you live in a small village miles away from all you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you know this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tone lightens) First food, no?  A good meal makes conversation so much easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned with the implications of what Romirez has said, l a robot Conor serves the meal.  His eyes never leave Romi who digs hungrily into the food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, que rico.  What is it you call this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pheasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Scots have a way with game.  It still has life in it. Spirit.  Back home the food is so...domestic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sent by his majesty of Spain to Inverness as a con- sultant on matters of metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a long way from Inverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my travels I heard the story of the MacLeod boy struck down and brought from the hand of death by powers not of this Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me home.  Me name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was time for our paths to cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez pulls back the sleeve on his cloak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He traces some discoloration on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the same?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it change with me in the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel you know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez and Conor walk alone amongst torch-lit hutches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me there could be only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some cling to sanity through time with the one continuity and trad0 ition their lives have known: The Game. (Conor confused) You and I Conor, we are different from all others around us.  You know this, you can feel it.  We are flesh and bone like any man, but unlike our neighbors we are rather difficult to injure, (looks away) permanently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are still so very young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm twenty-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Not even a single lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez chooses his words very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor, you and I, we cannot be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are immortal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, Conor backs away from Romirez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez grasps Conor's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushes away) No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all too much for Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me.  Hear the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is madness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez suddenly draws his sword and thrusts it into Cono heart.  The boy's mouth drops open in shocked terror as h eyes roll up into his head. A shudder, then Conor slides off the blade and crashes to ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna stops her car in front of the Washington Police De ment.  Getting out of her car she climbs the stairs but s After a moment of indecision she changes her mind and ret to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna lowers herself wearily into a chair, rubs her eyes and stares absently out the window. Reaching across to an end table, she plays back her answe machine. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Wickland at GWU.  Your test came back today.  You can call me here at the med center if you have any questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna, where the hell are you? The place is full of cops asking weird questions.  What's going on? I've got work stacking up.  Get in here right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna stands and goes to the kitchen, returning with a g of wine. Click. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She freezes in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My quarrel is not with you.  Meet me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna's eyes are glued on the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have much to talk of, you and I.  Answers for the young historian. (beat) O'Reily's.  Tonight.  I've grown to like taverns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. Beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Happy birthday to you, happy birth- day to you, happy birthday dear Brenna, happy birthday to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna is still upset from the last call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Brenna, it's mom.  Me and your neices just wanted to call and wish you a happy birthday.  Crissy made a real cute card for you, be sure to call her.  Will you be home for Easter?  Call when you can.  Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. Hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This HISS of Brenna's answering machine becomes the HISS cooking.  Bandaged about the chest, Conor asleep on his cot. Suddenly he sits up.  Sweating.  He looks about the room confusion as Romirez enters with a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three days you've laid there. It's time you ate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazed) This can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not dead, boy.  Accept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is monstrous.  I'll burn in hell for all eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have to die first. (extends forkful of food) Aqui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor starts CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is to become of me?  Am I to wander the Earth forever like a ghost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will live.  Survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they were right.  I am evil. This is God's punishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done nothing wrong Conor MacLeod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  Oh my God I'm lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days later. Nearly healed, Conor and Romirez stand near a quietly mov stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he want to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we cannot be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an imperfection.  For all your healing, if your head ever leaves your neck, you are dead. You can survive anything but steel against your threat.  Then it is over.  The end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I stop such a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hide.  Run to the ends of the Earth till you learn.  You must learn to defend yourself.  In this I can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are brothers.  And you are a defense- (beat) -of sorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old man, MR. NORTH, leads Taupin up the drive of a rur farmhouse somewhere in the hinterland of Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your father died I saw to it that the grounds were kept up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money in the estate was enough to cover your costs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, more than enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furniture clad in white sheets.  Dust everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the furniture was put into protective storage.  I'll have some boys come up and clean the place out for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin drags a finger across a dusty window pane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fascinated) You're one of William's kids, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His only kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure take after him.  Never seen a father and son look more alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The resemblance is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When may I expect the cleaners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send them right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coupled strangers gyrate under colored lights and recorde Brenna sits alone.  Whatever nervousness she brought thro door with her has been turned into a comfortable cynicism the three empty glasses in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: With something less than perfect coordination, sits down her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stuff'll put you away if you're not careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a Count.  Count Dusan.  He would invite the local peasants to his chateau, fill them full of wine, then slice their bellies so he could reuse it. (smiles) The symmetry of that somehow always appealed to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very macabre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna drains her glass and sets it down with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy a birthday girl a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small neighborhood tavern.  Regulars chat amicably with BARTENDER-OWNER.

dialogues.speaker: TAUPIN
dialogues.text: Sits alone at a corner table.  A WAITRESS hovers over him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lager and lime.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Taupin's lager is drained.  Lost in thought, he drags a f around and around the lip of the mug. He hand stops.  It twitches.  Shakes. Taupin pulls his hand from the glass and watches it shake out of control.  A warning. He WHIRLS around suddenly to see LING KAHN, Asian, standi over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacLeod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin is anxious, poised for attack. Kahn breaks into a broad smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare a chair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to offer me a chair or leave me standing here all night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn takes his place across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure) How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head still secure to the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many places this side of the Atlantic serve lager and lime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin looks to his own glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old habits die hard. (to waitress) Waitress!  A round of Nitzhic! (beat) Peasant drool, I know.  But it's the closest thing they stock to my side of the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the gathering, my friend.  The settling of old scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And have you something to settle with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Not tonight.  Tonight I have a drink with an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you, Kahn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress sets down two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, toast with me the past. (raises glass) To old conquests, old loves, and to a time when we cared about either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn drains his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waitress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn and Taupin sit drunkedly on the marble steps of a cl government building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never forget the look on that Papal commander's face when his "heretic stronghold" turned out to be a rock full of whores climbing all over Neuvich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neuvich, the clown of the crusades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then rides up Pope Pius who calmly brushes the dust from his papal cross, climbs off his papal horse, draws his papal sword and asks just what the hell is going on.  And what did Neuvich, dear dear drunken Neuvich do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offered the Pope one of his whores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They LAUGH. A JOGGER stops on the gravel and listens to the strange c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a great swing with his blade. For a Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Good times then.  A man could stretch his legs without bring- ing half the world down around his ears.  Not like now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jogger shakes his head and runs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious) He found us even there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLINKING of chain link as Taupin and Kahn climb a fence tumble into the Washington Zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't drunk this much since-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Since you last saw me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn chucks an empty wine bottle.  An unspecified animal sleepily somewhere in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin and Kahn stumble through an open-air display of As animals.  Their VOICES seem to echo everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love zoos.  Ever since I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn leans on the wall of a water buffalo pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points at one) I knew his great-grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, seriously.  We used to shoot pool together in Rangoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it, Kahn?  How do you live so full of life for so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasting and enjoying life is the only thing of value we have.  All else is just marking time. (beat) You're marking time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had a few more concerns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kahn jams his hands into his overcoat and starts down the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pressure only comes when you let the taste slip into your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't run as hard, MacLeod. You just don't run as hard anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late.  The bar is nearly empty. No sign of the Knight.  Brenna looks at her watch, sighs, drops a bill onto the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna has left the bar and is now walking down a dimly l street. She hears something and turns. -Nothing.  A breeze rustles the trees above. After only a few more paces she hears something again. Brenna abruptly turns. -Right into the face of THE KNIGHT. Brenna SCREAMS.  The Knight reaches into his leather carr

dialogues.speaker: A GROUP OF NOISY TEENAGERS
dialogues.text: Exit a facing townhouse.  The Knight removes his hand fro bag as they spill onto the sidewalk LAUGHING and YELLING. Brenna moves close to the group as they walk to the corne The Knight follows at a measured distance. At the corner the teenagers climb into a pickup and drive Brenna bolts into the intersection.  Weaving through SCRE brakes, she disappears into a pair of lighted glass doors

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 well dressed PATRONS, numbered cards pinned to their l sit in velvetly plush surroundings.  At the front of the stands a thin moustached art AUCTIONEER. Brenna BUSTLES in from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apoligize for the lateness of the hour, but I'm sure you will all agree the quality of this year's collection is well worth the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight BURSTS in with his leather carrying bag.  Bren slides along the draped back wall to avoid him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding statuette) For this fine example of medieval religious art, let us open the bid at 4,000 dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knight closes in on Brenna casually, without hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna raises her arm to attract the attention of a SECUR GUARD..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points at Brenna) 11,000.  A bid at 11,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard notices she has no lapel number and starts for very officially. Being closed in on from both sides, Brenna suddenly runs the room to a fire exit, setting off an ALARM as she flie the door. The Knight leaps after her, knocking over an OLD WOMAN in front row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna runs the sidewalk and disappears into a Metro stat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna runs down the platform and jumps into a subway car just as the doors shut.

dialogues.speaker: THE KNIGHT
dialogues.text: is also now on the platform but can only watch Brenna thr a window as the train pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna KNOCKS at the front door.  No answer. She KNOCKS harder.  The unlatched door pushes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenna stands in the doorway. Before her is a disaster.  Furniture has been smashed lik matchsticks.  A desk drawer's contents lie strewn in pile the floor. Brenna enters slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Taupin?  I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing has been left unturned or unbroken. Brenna kneels and sifts through a pile of crumpled papers She comes across an old black and white photograph.  Badl streaked and faded, it shows Taupin standing beside a far house.  Written in the corner is "Worstick, 1928". Brenna slips the photo into her pocket.  Standing, she tu smack into Taupin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks past her to the destruction of his living room. doesn't seem to surprise him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to kill me last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupont Circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin sifts through the debris, selecting articles from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment?  Carl Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ignores the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't worry Miss Cartwright. I've been at this a very long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called you "MacLeod".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left a man dead in Felton.  But you don't really care, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bothers you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.  Whatever I may or may not feel means exceedingly little to him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a witness to a murder.  That seems to put me pretty high on your friend's chop list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone to the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  I'm sure they'd love to hear your story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather hear yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You are being foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a historian, Mr. Taupin. Only once in a lifetime do you stare history in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he want to kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin stops, his back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees me as a threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taupin walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a clear rise above the village Romirez and Conor spar swords covered in heavy cloth.  Conor is having difficult

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concentrate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor thrusts.  Romirez blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harder.  Concentrate harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me arm hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.  Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor strikes.  Romirez easily blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harder!  You swing like an impotent cow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the boy has a mouth, now if only he had an arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticked off, Conor leans himself into a two-fisted swing. Romirez knocks it aside, but Conor recovers faster than h knocking Romirez flat on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impotent cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muy Bien!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor drops the sword and wipes the sweat from his face. Romirez pours wine from a leather bag into a goblet pulle from his belt.  He offers it to Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here my boy, from vineyards as sweet and smooth as a young girl's thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor accepts the cup.  Romirez pulls himself to his feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will take less effort as you learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like to kill me first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez puts his arm around Conor and refills his cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a gift.  One you must protect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is this great gift that cannot be seen or smelt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fabric of life.  The spark that allows the passing of existence from one generation to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) If that was meant to be an ex- planation Mr. Romirez from Spain, I'm afraid you've failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romirez put his arm around Conor and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.  Enough sword play for an afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friendly horse race.  Their reflections bouncing off a glen, Conor and Romirez dodge moss-laiden ruts and leap f tree trunks. Beaming, Conor pushes through a last turn and stops to wa for Romirez, several lengths behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Romirez rides up) You're no match for Scot, Mr. Romirez.  We're raised as riders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point conceeded, Mr. MacLeod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both their eyes turn to the beauty in view.  Romirez pull leaf from a tree and studies it closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the fascinatioon?  It is only a leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All living things pay dues, Conor.  They must be respected for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the leaf's points from the stalk, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not think I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel hardly nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why be so concerned about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not ready for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VILLAGER approaches from across the pasture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Darin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
